hints.content: Start by understanding the cost of collecting chocolates. The cost of collecting a chocolate at index i is given by nums[i]. You need to collect chocolates of all types, which means you will need to consider the indices of the array.

Consider how the operation affects the types of chocolates. When you perform the operation, every chocolate type shifts to the next index, wrapping around to the beginning of the array. Think about how many operations you might need to perform to collect all types.
Think about the costs involved. For each chocolate type, you can either collect it directly or perform operations to collect it later. Calculate the total cost for both strategies and compare them.

Notice that the cost of performing operations is constant (x) regardless of how many chocolates you have collected. This means you need to balance the cost of operations with the cost of collecting chocolates.

You can simulate the process of collecting chocolates and performing operations. Start by collecting each chocolate type at its cost, then try performing operations and see how it affects your total cost. Keep track of the minimum cost encountered.

Consider edge cases, such as when the cost of operations is very high compared to the cost of collecting chocolates. In such cases, it might be better to collect chocolates directly without performing any operations.

You can use a loop to iterate through the array and simulate the collection of chocolates. For each chocolate type, calculate the cost of collecting it directly and the cost of performing operations to collect it later.

Think about using a dynamic programming approach or a greedy strategy to minimize the total cost. You might want to keep track of the cumulative cost as you decide whether to perform operations or collect chocolates.

When you calculate the total cost, remember to include the cost of operations each time you decide to shift the chocolate types. This will help you determine whether it's worth it to perform an operation or just collect the chocolate directly.

Finally, consider how to structure your solution. You might want to create a function that calculates the minimum cost based on the current state of chocolate types and the costs involved. Make sure to test your solution with edge cases.

questionNotes: You can perform as many operations as you want.
Each chocolate type is unique initially.
